body.head:
Forest Leaves
Ethiopia*
body.annotation: Harper revised this poem for her 1854 Poems on Miscellaneus Subjects. It was reprinted in Augues 24, 1855 issue of Frederick Douglass' Paper.

lg.l: Her bleeding hands abroad,Psalm 68:31.In the Old Testament, Ethiopia refers not to the modern kingdom of Ethiopia, but to an ancient Nubia, the modern Sudan. In its nineteenth-century usage, the term "Ethiopian" referred more generally to people of African descent, rather than to the region or nation of Ethiopiamore specifically. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, the use of "Ethiop" to refer to " a black or dark-skinned person; a black African" dates to as early as the fourteenth century. This use was also prominent in other African American writing, as in that of Harper's predecessor, Phillis Wheatley, who refers to herself as "An Ethiop" inTo the University of Cambridge, in New England"(1773)
Her cry of agony shall reach
The tyrant's yoke from off her neck,
The mighty hand of Godshall break,
Redeem'dRedeemedfrom dust and freed from chains
Her sons shall lift their eyes
From cloud capt hills and verdantverdant: green with grass, rich vegetationplains
Shall play a smile of peace
For God hath bent unto her woe
And aged sires with joyous psalms,
Secure by night, and blest by day
Nor human tigers hunt for prey
Thy cry of agony shall reach
